Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Award: DMS 1612020, Principal Investigator: Agnes Beaudry

The project supported by this grant is part of a large scale effort to understand the homotopy groups of spheres, one of the fundamental problems in algebraic topology. The spheres, which are among the simplest geometric objects, are building blocks for more complex entities. The homotopy groups of spheres, which are used to study the connections between these basic components, are collections of continuous functions between spheres considered up to deformations. Many problems in other fields, especially differential topology, have been reduced to the study of these groups, which is notoriously difficult. However, a bridge has been built between algebraic geometry and algebraic topology that allows us to use sophisticated algebraic theory to enable calculations of the homotopy groups of spheres. This bridge is known as chromatic homotopy theory. This project studies two of the most important structural conjectures in this field, the telescope and chromatic splitting conjectures. It has a strong computational component that will provide data to help study these two fundamental problems.

Chromatic homotopy theory uses higher analogues of K-theory which give rise to higher periodicity in the stable homotopy groups of spheres. The chromatic splitting conjecture is an attempt at explaining the relationship between different periodicities. Recently, the PI has disproved a special case of this conjecture. In a project with Goerss and Henn, the PI aims to explain this failure and reformulate the conjecture. In a related project with Xu, the PI plans to compute the homotopy groups of the K(2)-local sphere at the prime two. These computations use self-dual resolutions which appear to be related to Brown-Commenetz duality and the structure of the K(2)-local Picard group. The PI plans to study this connection with Bobkova, Goerss and Henn. A parallel part of the project is to study periodicity in relation to the telescope conjecture. In work with Behrens, Bhattacharya, Culver and Xu, the PI plans to detect periodic elements using a resolution of the sphere by topological modular forms. The telescope conjecture gives a connection between periodic elements detected by such methods and those detected by the K(2)-local sphere. Comparing the two computations may shed light on this conjecture.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

This award was part of an ongoing large scale effort to understand the homotopy groups of spheres, a fundamental problem in topology. The spheres, which are among the simplest geometric objects, are building blocks for more complex entities. The homotopy groups of spheres are collections of continuous functions between spheres considered up to deformations. They are used to study the connections between these basic components. The area of mathematics which studies these groups is called homotopy theory. This field has connections with other areas of mathematics, for example with number theory as interesting functions and sequences appear as patterns and structure in the homotopy groups of spheres. There are connections with differential geometry as these groups play a role in studying geometric objects. Homotopy theory has applications to physics in the classification of phases of matter.

Although the study of the homotopy groups of spheres is notoriously difficult, a bridge has been built between algebraic geometry and homotopy theory that allows us to use sophisticated algebraic theory to enable calculations. This bridge is called chromatic homotopy theory and was the main theme of the award.

The philosophy of chromatic homotopy theory is that the homotopy groups of spheres (specifically, the p-local stable groups for a prime number p) are divided into families called the chromatic layers. There is one family for each natural number n (called the height) and it corresponds to collections of elements that repeat at a certain frequency. The terminology is meant to remind us of the electromagnetic spectrum. Two of the most important open problems about these families, the Chromatic Splitting Conjecture and the Telescope Conjecture, were at the center of this award. The Chromatic Splitting Conjecture is important to understand how the different frequencies interact with each other. The Telescope Conjecture gives geometric meaning to periodicities defined in terms of algebra.

Intellectual Merit

The award's main focus was computations in chromatic homotopy theory in cases at "tipping points" in difficulty (when the height n is small with respect to p). Here, patterns become more complicated and new phenomena arise. One of the greatest impact of this project was to produce data which has led to a better understanding of general patterns, has helped answer open questions, and has given rise to new predictions. 

Most notably, the project advanced our understanding of the Chromatic Splitting Conjecture, which comes in a weak and a strong form. The weak form predicts that certain pieces of the chromatic layers are disconnected from one another. The strong form explains in more detail how the layers are expected to interact as a whole. The PI disproved the strong Chromatic Splitting Conjecture in a special case (at n=p=2, arXiv:1502.02190). A major accomplishment of this award was work of the PI and collaborators which explained exactly how the conjecture failed and described what happens instead (arXiv:1712.08182). This provided insight on how to reformulate the strong Chromatic Splitting Conjecture. Furthermore, the PI and co-authors proved that, despite the failure of the strong conjecture, the weak conjecture holds true in this case. This was the last unknown case for the weak Chromatic Splitting Conjecture when the height n is at most 2. 

Another major focus of the award was to apply a computational tool called the tmf-Adams spectral sequence to study stable homotopy groups as well as the Telescope Conjecture (arXiv:1909.13379). Because of the complexity of tmf (topological modular forms), the tmf-Adams spectral sequence has not been used often in computations. However, by applying it to objects with simplifying features, the PI and collaborators were able to perform new computations and solve an open question. The work revealed intricate patterns that are consistent with predictions that the Telescope Conjecture is generally false.

The award also led to other computational and structural results in chromatic and stable homotopy theory (arXiv:1702.00230, arXiv:1712.09083, arXiv:1705.07036, arXiv:1810.06651, arXiv:1901.02109, arXiv:1801.07559, arXiv:1611.00382).

Broader Impacts

This award had many educational components. The PI mentored undergraduate and graduate research on topics in homotopy theory. The award also supported graduate student summer fellowships as well as student travel to conferences. The PI (with co-authors) produced two expository pieces: An article which explains how to do computations in stable homotopy theory that have applications in mathematical physics (arXiv:1801.07530) and a chapter on chromatic homotopy theory which appeared in the Handbook of Homotopy Theory (arXiv:1901.09004). The PI also organized conferences and workshops. In particular, the award helped support the conference Chromatic Homotopy Theory: Journey to the Frontier for which videos and other educational materials are now available permanently online, providing resources for those learning the field.
